comments.body:
- [x] Step 1: manually merge near-duplicates with one of them having source "uncontrolled", "LAE", "ingest"
- [x] Step2: merge "uncontrolled", "LAE", "ingest" into "local"
- [x] Step 3: merge remaining near-duplicates

Having completed this process, the following source values are in production:
```
local
nad
ulan
viaf
lcnaf
lcsh
snac
```

After deduping, the following source codes are in production:
```
aat
gmgpc
lcsh
lcnaf
local
mesh
rbgenr
tgn
ftamc
viaf
rbprov
rbpri
tgm
faat
alcsh
abne
homoit
```

orangelight.title: Design the biased search results reporting form
Create and document evaluation and response workflow for biased search results form submissions

comments.body:
Harmful description/descriptive metadata form in Orangelight and harmful language form in Finding Aids are both using LibAnswers queues right now.

The form in Orangelight only goes to the IRMWG group chairs.  The scope of that form is specifically on the descriptive metadata for catalog items, not the content of the items themselves.  The Finding Aids form is called the "Report Harmful Language or Content Form" and refers to both descriptive metadata and the content itself.
Next step will be to engage IRMWG chairs for guidance; Kate will contact Phoebe and Lia today.

orangelight.title: Measure success of initial work on biased search results form feature
Choose Solr Highlighting Option

comments.body:
Solr documentation, [Unified option](https://solr.apache.org/guide/solr/latest/query-guide/highlighting.html#unified-highlighter).
According to the documentation it looks like the unified option is the one to choose and implement. The last paragraph confused me a little bit but I hope that adding the unified option highlighting doesn't mean that we ignore the boosted fields. Most likely the specs (related to boosted fields) will let us know. : 
```
The Unified Highlighter is the newest highlighter (as of Solr 6.4), which stands out as the most performant and accurate of the options. It can handle typical requirements and others possibly via plugins/extension. We recommend that you use this highlighter as a first choice.

The UH highlights a query very accurately and thus is true to what the underlying Lucene query actually matches.

A strong benefit to this highlighter is that you can opt to configure Solr to put more information in the underlying index to speed up highlighting of large documents; multiple configurations are supported, even on a per-field basis. There is little or no such flexibility of offset sources for the other highlighters. More on this below.

There are some reasons not to choose this highlighter: Passage scoring does not consider boosts in the query. Some users want more/better passage breaking flexibility. The "alternate" fallback options are more primitive.
```

orangelight.title: Find and define all the ways we could switch search relevancy in the backend and define them here

comments.body:
Ways we could switch search relevancy:

No matter what we do is a new search builder.

1. Solr Request Handler
   * Define it in the solrconfig
   * New Search Builder would submit with "qt=different_algorithm" instead of "qt=search"
   * Pros: Maximum functionality, hides a bunch of parameters.
   * Cons: Have to maintain two request handlers, have to deploy.
2. Add weights to the search query Blacklight sends
   * This was done in an earlier test: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ROvFH-dy2pWneRmouYZiHvnSBSxGkLt7ygb6CCsx1-Y/edit
   * Example:
      ```
       http://localhost:9793/solr/catalog-alma-production/select?boost=div(1%2Csub(sum(floor(div(ms(NOW)%2C%20mul(1000%2C%2060%2C%2060%2C%2024%2C%20365)))%2C1971)%2C%20pub_date_start_sort))&defType=edismax&fl=*%2Cdiv(1%2Csub(sum(floor(div(ms(NOW)%2C%20mul(1000%2C%2060%2C%2060%2C%2024%2C%20365)))%2C1971)%2C%20pub_date_start_sort))&q=black%20teenagers&stopwords=true 
      ```
      * Option 2B
         * Maybe we could implement this by storing a boost value in a solr field, resulting in a solr query like `select?boost=boost_sort`
      * That group found that the

orangelight.title: How should algorithm switching be implemented such that it goes into the code base?

comments.body: I think the feature flipper is the best way forward. It is an accepted and well-understood pattern on the DACS team, and this feature is new enough that we're not even sure we're going to commit fully to it, so it seems premature to ask the Blacklight community to take on its maintenance.

Documentation PRs can be merged outside a feature flipper
Code PRs need to be behind a feature flipper

princeton_ansible.title: Added search and race teams as admins
Enable Additional Devs to Use the Feature Flipper
First steps to nginx config template

comments.body:
Known remaining work to a first-round merge:
- [x] add a directory for templated config
- [x] include the templated config directory in the main nginx config file, so both static and templated config files are loaded by the load balancer
- [x] update the task to send the templated files to that new directory
- [x] remove the `template_test` tag
- [ ] find a way to remove unneeded/old files from the /etc/nginx/conf.d/dynamic directory
- [ ] make sure the SSL directories on the load balancer match the directory names in the /etc/nginx/conf.d/dynamic/*.conf files.  Use roles/nginxplus/vars/main.yml to create the SSL certificates in the appropriate directory structure.
- [ ] Update /etc/nginx/nginx.conf to include the dynamic directory configs, either manually or by running playbooks/nginxplus_production_rebuild.yml.
- [ ] test playbook again
